generif.text: Describes the role of CTRP5 in disease, in addition to the bicistronic nature of CTRP5 and MFRP, which is confirmed by RT-PCR.
Extreme hyperopia (Nanophthalmos) is the result of null mutations in MFRP.
Mutation of the membrane-type frizzled-related protein gene is associated with inherited retinal degenerations
Defects in MFRP could be responsible for syndromic forms of microphthalmos/retinal degeneration. This gene is necessary for photoreceptor maintenance.
Observational study of gene-disease association. (HuGE Navigator)
These results indicate that the MFRP gene may not play a role in regulating ocular axial length in these phenotypes.

Patients without MFRP gene function exhibit no correction of refractive error during childhood, which suggests that this gene is essential for emmetropization, a complex process by which vision regulates axial growth of the eye.

The novel frameshift mutation identified in the family described here validates MFRP as the gene responsible for this particular disease, which characteristically involves structures located at the posterior segment of the eye.
These results do not support a significant role for CHX10 or MFRP mutations in primary angle closure glaucoma.
Significant associations between angle-closure glaucoma and sequence variants in the MFRP gene, was analyzed.
MFRP is less likely to play a major role in physiologic high hyperopia.
Observational study of gene-disease association. (HuGE Navigator)
This is the first demonstration of compound heterozygosity for MFRP mutations.
Three novel MFRP mutations that expand the phenotypic data available on patients with MFRP mutations, are reported.
In both previous reports of PMPRS, mutations in membrane type frizzled-related protein (MFRP) gene (located at 11q23) was demonstrated to be present
Posterior microphthalmos can be caused by nonsense compound heterozygous mutations in the MFRP gene.
Homozygous autosomal recessive retinitis pigmentosa-causing mutations have been found in three Indian families. These included a single base deletion in MFRP.
MFRP gene shows tendency to be associated with primary angle closure glaucoma in both the Australian and Nepalese cohorts.

Corneal diameter decreases with decreasing axial length, suggesting posterior microphthalmos and nanophthalmos represent a spectrum of high hyperopia rather than distinct phenotypes. In the Saudi population PRSS56 mutations are the major cause.
nanophthalmos and high hyperopia but without electrophysiological evidence of retinal dystrophy has also been associated with MFRP mutations.
Among five single nucleotide polymorphism(SNP)s tested, only MFRP rs3814762 and heat shock protein (HSP)70 rs1043618 show nominal association with primary angle closure.
The current study expands our knowledge of the mutation spectrum of MFRP and its associated phenotypes. To our knowledge, this is the first report of MFRP mutations in a Chinese cohort.
We report the MFRP-related ocular phenotype in three siblings with glycogen storage disease type 1b. Molecular genetic studies identified novel mutations in the MFRP and SLC37A4 genes.
MFRP mutation is associated with posterior microphthalmos, retinitis pigmentosa, and foveoschisis.

This is the first trio-based whole-genome sequencing (WGS), study for nanophthalmos, revealing the potential role of de novo mutations (DNMs) in MYRF and rare inherited genetic variants in PRSS56 and MFRP.
The majority of autosomal recessive nanophthalmos and posterior microphthalmia can be attributed to biallelic sequence and structural variants in MFRP and PRSS56.
Novel mutations in MFRP and PRSS56 are associated with posterior microphthalmos.
A novel MFRP gene variant in a family with posterior microphthalmos, retinitis pigmentosa, foveoschisis, and foveal hypoplasia.
Genotype-phenotype spectrum in isolated and syndromic nanophthalmos.
Novel TMEM98, MFRP, PRSS56 variants in a large United States high hyperopia and nanophthalmos cohort.
Membrane Frizzled-Related Protein-Related Disease Mimicking Idiopathic Intracranial Hypertension.
Pathogenic variants of MFRP and PRSS56 genes are major causes of nanophthalmos in Japanese patients.

BP.term: embryo development ending in birth or egg hatching

interpro.desc: Low-density lipoprotein (LDL) receptor class A repeat
Low-density lipoprotein (LDL) receptor class A, conserved site

name: membrane frizzled-related protein
summary: This gene encodes a member of the frizzled-related protein family. The encoded protein plays an important role in eye development and mutations in this gene have been associated with nanophthalmos, posterior microphthalmia, retinitis pigmentosa, foveoschisis, and optic disc drusen. The protein is encoded by a bicistronic transcript which also encodes C1q and tumor necrosis factor related protein 5 (C1QTNF5). [provided by RefSeq, Jun 2013].
